The Harvard University Annual Lowell Lecture

 

Bernard Bailyn on His Book

 

The Barbarous Years

 

Lowell, Russell, and Harvard ...

... with Tales from The Barbarous Years

:: :: ::

This year’s Lowell Lecture features Bernard Bailyn, Adams University Professor and James Duncan Phillips Professor of Early American History, emeritus at Harvard. The lecture will be on Bertrand Russell’s experiences as a Lowell lecturer, the emergence of Harvard’s governance in the early years, and the fate of other idealistic projects in the barbarism of the seventeenth century.

Free and open to the public.

:: :: ::

Wednesday, April 17, 2013 - 8pm
Sever Hall, room 113
Harvard Yard
Cambridge, MA


Bernard Bailyn: Professor Bailyn’s historical work centers on early American history, the American Revolution, and the Atlantic world in the pre-industrial era. He has taught at Harvard for many years, and is the author of numerous books including The Ideological Origins of the American Revolution (1967) and Voyagers to the West (1986), both of which won Pulitzer Prizes, and The Ordeal of Thomas Hutchinson (1974), which won the National Book Award in History. He is also the recipient of many other awards, including the National Humanities Medal in 2011.

In his latest book, The Barbarous Years: The Peopling of British North America – The Conflict of Civilizations 1600-1675 (2012) Bailyn gives a compelling account of the first great transit of people from Britain, Europe, and Africa to British North America. Their involvements with each other and their struggles with the indigenous peoples of the eastern seaboard are detailed in the book. According to Publishers Weekly, “This weighty book distills a lifetime of learning of one of our most authoritative historians of colonial America...A history of the colonies built up of brilliant portraits of the people who interacted in these strange and fearsome lands.”

He served as editor-in-chief of the John Harvard Library from 1962 to 1970, as co-editor of the journal Perspectives in American History, from 1967 to 1977 and 1984 to 1986, as director of the Charles Warren Center for Studies in American History from 1983 to 1994, and as Director of the International Seminar on the History of the Atlantic World since 1996. He was also a senior fellow in the Society of Fellows from 1982 to 2005.

This event is free and open to the public. It is sponsored by Harvard Extension School and the Lowell Institute of Boston.
